prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral setup - I
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 12CO, 13CO, C18O J=2-1 SiO J=5-4 DCO+ J=3-2 continuum at 233-235 GHz (searched for best line-free regions)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to observe the J=2-1 transitions of the three isotopologues of CO in Band 6, as well as the SiO J=5-4, DCO+ J=3-2 transitions and the 1.3mm continuum. The 13CS J=5-4 also falls in the selected bands.
All targets in our sample are bright, especially in the CO transitions. The sensitivity request is driven by the need to detect the faint CO wing emission lying some 30 km/s or so from the line centre. Based on our JCMT data, as well as other data in the literature, a sensitivity requirement of 0.3K is sufficient to detect these line wings.
For the other transitions, the integrated line intensity and/or the peak line flux is required to achieve our science goals to determine the spatial distribution of the emission and to measure velocity gradients.
Sanchez-Monge et al. (2013) studied 14 high mass outflows using the IRAM 30m and found that the typical peak brightness of the SiO 5-4 line is ~ 0.3K. The velocity widths of the line are typically 30-50 km/s. We have set the spectral averaging in the Spectral Setup to 16 for this (and the DCO+) transition such that the sensitivity in the spectrum will be 0.15K in a 1.2 km/s channel. Further binning in software will be required to detect the faintest in the sample (~ 0.1K peak) as the more evolved sources are predicted to be fainter.
The 13CS is typically of the same brightness as the C18O (~2-6K in our JCMT data) and will reliably trace the circumstellar disk.
Continuum sensitivity will not be an issue as the minimum expected flux density is ~ 10mJy and the instrument sensitivity is 0.06mJy.
Use of the ACA is requested to obtain the total power and to recover the largest spatial scales (~ 25") for the science goals - see Figure 3. The spatial resolution of ~ 0.7" is sufficient to measure opening angles/collimation factors, and to resolve velocity gradients across the 5-10" breadth of the flow, in our search for jet/outflow rotation.
In order to simultaneously observe CO, 13CO and C18O requires small spectral window setups. Here, the lowest resolution possible is 0.15km/s, higher than is required for our science goals. We therefore propose to bin our data to 0.3 km/s (1.2 km/s for SiO) - using a spectral average of 4 in the Spectral Setup - to increase our per channel sensitivity. This retains ample spectral resolution to measure the high velocity wings from the outflow, as well as to measure velocity gradients in the first moment (line peak velocity) thus any rotation signatures across the flow. We expect to find rotation of the order of 2-5 km/s across the breadth of the flow (see Figure 4).
The CO lines will allow us to trace the full velocity extent of the outflow - with the 13CO allowing us to measure the outflow where the 12CO may go optically thick. The integrated emission of the SiO will be used to trace the jet structure. Finally, the DCO+, 13CS and 1.3mm contiuum will allow us to, primarily, detect the presence of a circumstellar disk and, secondary, the lines will allow us to search for and estimate it's sense of rotation which we can use to compare to any outflow rotation that we detect.
We will obtain these data in one spectral setup of the correlator, making the most efficient use of ALMA's versatility that we can. This configuration requires an on-source integration time of just over 12 minutes for each target.
Due to the location of some of our targets, two separate science goals have been created. Altogether, including calibrations, the 10 targets in our proposal will require 4 hours of integration time with the main array, and approximately 17 hours required for the ACA.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spectral setup - II
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 12CO, 13CO, C18O J=2-1 SiO J=5-4 DCO+ J=3-2 continuum at 233-235 GHz (searched for best line-free regions)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The formation and rapid evolution of high mass stars onto the main sequence is poorly understood. Our aim is to establish an observational basis to theoretical models that describe an evolutionary process distinguished by the morphology of molecular outflows. If correct, the consequence is high mass star formation must be a scaled-up version of low mass star formation, i.e. accretion and outflow mediated and driven via a disk. Given the large distances and clustered nature of high mass star formation, differentiating between an outflow that is driven by a single protostar or by the collective contribution of the cluster requires the spatial resolution of ALMA.
Now that ALMA is available in Cycle 2, the sensitivity and spatial resolution is available to tackle this problem head on. We will target a number of sources with known outflows, distances and dynamical ages. This will give us the platform to establish whether the proposed evolution (first proposed nearly a decade ago) truly exists. At the same time, we will test models by examining the onset and evolution of kink instabilities within the jet, and to search for signatures of rotation of the outflow.
